The loan he is requesting from Fundación Campo is to buy 300 broiler chickens, 2 milk cows, and 2 calves. The rest of the financing will be used to repair the chain-link fence where the chickens are, since it is in bad shape.

With the loan, he will increase his herd of cattle and raise 300 broiler chickens, since he currently has 300 others that are ready for sale. His inventory will increase on buying all these chickens and therefore his sales will be larger and of course his earnings as well. In this way, he will be able to make other investments he is thinking of.

His goals are: first, he wants to build one more coop to raise the chickens, since the one he currently has is very small and is in pretty bad shape. He also wants to build feed and water troughs for the cattle. And finally, he wants to continue studying for a university degree.

loans.use: to buy 300 broiler chickens, 2 milk cows, and 2 calves. The rest of the financing will be used to repair the chain-link fence where the chickens are, since it is in bad shape.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda is 52 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school, Belinda works very hard to provide for them.

Belinda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase stocks like chips, bread, soft drinks, canned goods, milk, egg, etc to sell.

Belinda has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Belinda would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase chips, bread, soft drinks, canned goods, milk, eggs, etc to sell

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 49 years old and married with five children.

Jenny works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like soap, canned goods, milk, chips, etc.

Jenny has borrowed and paid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from buying and selling cosmetics products.

Jenny aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like soap, canned goods, milk, chips, etc.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is 40 years-old and married with three children who are all in school. 

Marlyn is in the agricultural business and she farms vegetables in the Philippines. Marlyn has requested a PHP 19,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Marlyn has been farming vegetables for ten years now and has borrowed 12 times in the past from NWTF.

In the future, Marlyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Shamshad

texts.en:
Shamshad is a 37-year-old responsible mother of three children. She is living in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, along with her husband in a rented house. Her husband has been running a garment shop for three years, and this is the only source of income for her family. Her household expenses are very large compared to the business income, because of which she is facing a lot of financial problems in life.

She has requested a loan from Kiva’s partner, BRAC Pakistan. With the loan amount, her husband would buy a new variety of dresses, shirts, jeans, and suits to attract more customers. His sales would be increased in this way, and his monthly income and savings would also be increased.

loans.use: to purchase a new variety of garments.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fruit selling business in the Philippines.

Teresita has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell from her food stall.

She has been in this business for 15 years.

In the future, Teresita would like to save enough to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell from her food stall.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda, de 38 años de edad , está casada y tiene 02 hijos pequeños a quienes brinda todo su amor y cuidado en la casa propia que logro obtener gracias a sus esfuerzos. Hilda se dedica a la venta de pescado fresco, todos los días se dirige al puerto pesquero de la ciudad para adquirir los pescados al por mayor, luego se encarga de distribuirlos por especies y tamaños, finalmente los pone a la venta por kilos llegando muchas veces a triplicar su inversión inicial. Trabaja sola y se encarga de vender los pescados luego de obtenerlos de sus proveedores ya establecidos, sus clientes varían entre los compradores eventuales y comerciantes de pescado de la ciudad, tiene como principal herramienta su gran carisma y elocuencia para acceder a los clientes. Lleva 10 años en éste trabajo y ha aprendido mucho sobre el manejo y las temporadas de pesca por está razón se ha convertido en una excelente administradora de su negocio y siempre recibe buenas ganancias por su trabajo. Le gusta lo que hace y tiene buenos ingresos aunque su única incomodidad es no tener un puesto fijo para realizar sus ventas, por lo que tiene que vender en el mismo lugar en donde adquiere los pescados producto de las jornadas de pesca. Este es su séptimo crédito con Kiva, por tanto agradece la oportunidad y confianza que le brindan para continuar con su negocio razón por la cual se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual.
El monto solicitado de 1000 soles lo invertirá en la compra de pescados al por mayor.
texts.en:
Hilda, 38 years old, is married and has 2 small children, to whom she provides all of her love and care in her own house, which she succeeded in obtaining thanks to her efforts. Hilda sells fresh fish. Every day she goes to the fishing port of the city to acquire wholesale fish. She then sorts them by species and size, and finally she puts them up for sale by the kilo, often tripling her initial investment. She works alone, and she sells the fish after obtaining them from already established providers. Her customers vary between casual customers and fish traders from the city. Her main tool to gain customers is her great charisma and eloquence. She has been doing this work for 10 years, and she has learned a lot about the management of fish and its seasons. Because of this, she has become an excellent administrator of her business, and she always receives a good profit from her work. She likes what she does, and she has a good income, although her only irritation is not to have a fixed place to sell. For this reason, she has to sell in the same place where she acquires the fish, which depends on the fishing day. This is her seventh loan with Kiva, so she is thankful for the opportunity and confidence they give her to continue with her business. She therefore promises to make her loan repayments in a punctual manner. 

She will use the amount requested of 1000 soles to buy wholesale fish.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fish

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
This is Marites. She previously accessed a 12,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her rug-making business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children, and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another loan, this time for 15,000 PHP, to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marites dreams that her business will continue to grow. She meets with her co-fellowship members* every week, to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for cloth, thread and other materials she needs for her rug-making business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Anita works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetables and fruits vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rice and coconut. 

Anita is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy additional vegetables and fruits like eggplant, string beans, squash, mangoes, avocados, etc. to sell for her vegetables and fruits vending business.

Anita has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables and fruits like eggplant, string beans, squash, mangoes, avocados, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Kamengo United Group

texts.en: Yusta is a member of the above-mentioned group where each one guarantees the other in accessing a loan. She is 49 years old and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her main business is running a fresh food business alongside catering to boost her income.She faces the challenges of the perishability of her stock due to lack of appropriate preservation equipment and her vision is educating her children to higher levels of learning and buying refrigerators. Yusta is requesting a loan to buy fresh foods to sell.

loans.use: to buy fresh foods to sell.

loans.name: Ivane

texts.en:
Ivane is from a small village in Terjola district. He has a large family which includes parents, his wife, brother, daughter-in-law and two cousins.  In the past, Ivane has requested loans several times from local financial institutions in order to start-up a family business but without any success. His loan requests have all been rejected due to low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The family is actively involved in agricultural activities.  Specifically, they have three milking cows whose milk is used to make cheese products. In addition, they have a vineyard with 1200 wine trees. They pick grapes seasonally and produce wine to sell. They sell wine and cheese locally at a good price. However, there is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimates, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Ivane has requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business and he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative from Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as high risk borrowers because of their low income. With his credit, Ivane will purchase a minibus and will begin trade with groceries. He will transport groceries to sell with his minibus to different villages.  This will be an additional source of income for his large family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a minibus to transport vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Aliya

texts.en: Aliya is a 30-year-old diligent woman. She is living in Rawalpindi, Pakistan along with her husband and two children. She has been doing the business of selling leather products for five years. Currently, she needs to purchase new leather products and for that purpose, she has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan. Her monthly sales would be increased with the addition of a new variety of leather products. She is very thankful for Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase leather products to sell

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
This is Rosana. She previously accessed a 14,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase materials and additional equipment for her propeller business. Her earnings were a big help towards the education of her children, and personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another loan of 30,000 PHP in order to buy materials and additional equipment for her propeller business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and pay for the children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Rosanna hopes that her business will continue to grow and dreams that her children will have a good education and future. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for materials and additional equipment for her propeller business.

loans.name: Analina

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Analina works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending and charcoal retail businesses. Analina is borrowing PHP 29,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell to her customers.

Analina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
Edelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring shop business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy additional materials such as cloths, needles, thread, etc. for her tailoring shop business.

Edelyn has been in this business for four years. Edelyn earns additional income from food processing.

Edelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional materials such as cloths, needles, thread, etc.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is married and blessed with six children who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She cooks food for sale at the market and sells to town dwellers and passersby who are her clients. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to expand her business

loans.use: to purchase beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
Sylvia is a young businesswoman, aged 28 years, who operates a restaurant at Nakasero market. She started this business last year after having difficulties with the charcoal selling business.

She has applied for a loan of ugx.1,000,000/= (one million shillings) in order to add stock to her business. She wants to buy new plates in order to serve her increasing clients better and to replace the old plates. Sylvia intends to use the profits made by the help of the loan to pay back the loan installment and to complete her house in Nansana so that she can improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy plates.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a 39 year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She is the mother of a 13 year-old daughter. She operates a motorcycle transport service.

In addition to operating a motorcycle transport services, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store.  She sells various goods ranging from eggs, cooking oil, sugar, noodles and canned goods. Mary Ann has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP in order to buy more goods for the store and to purchase school supplies and food for the family.  

Mary Ann would like to expand both her businesses in order to be able to send her child to a college education.

loans.use: to buy more goods for the store and school supplies and food for the family
